problemDomain.title: The Problem Domain
content: Academic scheduling sits at the intersection of people, time, and limited resources. Universities must assign lecturers and TAs to courses, rooms, and time slots while respecting a dense web of constraints: individual availability, institutional policies, room capacities, equipment needs, and fairness considerations.

The domain is multi-stakeholder: Lecturers care about realistic workloads and personal constraints; Managers care about coverage and compliance; Organizations care about standardizing processes and ensuring data security.

Many institutions still manage scheduling with tools not designed for it: spreadsheets, email threads, and legacy systems. These make it hard to maintain a single source of truth, see conflicts early, ensure fairness, and react to changes during the semester.

vision.title: Our Vision
content: The vision is to provide a SaaS-based academic scheduling platform that turns the messy manual process into a transparent, data-driven workflow. Instead of treating scheduling as a painful one-off event each semester, we see it as a living process that can adapt to new information.

Lecturers and TAs get simple, friendly interfaces to express availability and preferences in natural language. Managers get powerful tools to define slots, run auto-assignment, review conflicts, and adjust with full manual control.

A central design principle is trustworthy automation: The auto-assignment engine proposes schedules based on availability and rules, but it's never a black box. Managers can see why assignments were made, override when needed, and re-run while preserving critical decisions.
The system makes fairness and resilience first-class concerns, tracking unpopular shifts, workload limits, and rest periods to help distribute duties equitably over time.
